messages.text: I am using PackageCompiler to generate a sysimage that is packaged in a Docker container and run on an EC2 instance. I can launch the container fine locally, but on EC2 I get this error: `ERROR: Unable to find compatible target in system image.` From a review of some GitHub issues, I understand that this may be because the sysimage is being generated for my exact cpu arch and therefore cannot transfer to the EC2 instance. How do I get PackageCompiler to generate a sysimage for a more general x86_64 target?

elements.text: I am using PackageCompiler to generate a sysimage that is packaged in a Docker container and run on an EC2 instance. I can launch the container fine locally, but on EC2 I get this error:
ERROR: Unable to find compatible target in system image.

From a review of some GitHub issues, I understand that this may be because the sysimage is being generated for my exact cpu arch and therefore cannot transfer to the EC2 instance. How do I get PackageCompiler to generate a sysimage for a more general x86_64 target?

messages.text: There is the `cpu_target` keyword argument

elements.text: There is the
cpu_target
keyword argument

messages.text: You can set it to <https://github.com/JuliaLang/PackageCompiler.jl/blob/2d8010d8be72d65269d114b037be35081ec7f303/src/PackageCompiler.jl#L18|https://github.com/JuliaLang/PackageCompiler.jl/blob/2d8010d8be72d65269d114b037be35081ec7f303/src/PackageCompiler.jl#L18>

elements.text: You can set it to
https://github.com/JuliaLang/PackageCompiler.jl/blob/2d8010d8be72d65269d114b037be35081ec7f303/src/PackageCompiler.jl#L18

messages.text:
Oh, I missed that one. Thanks, I will try that.
Edit: That worked

elements.text:
Hello everyone,

messages.text: I'm looking into building a static app using PackageCompiler, and I was initially hoping to be able to have a single self-contained binary file that I could run. It appears that I get a directory instead, with a lib folder etc. Could someone please help me understand what role all of this plays, and whether or not any of it can be discarded? Having a single binary (statically linked) is much nicer to distribute and run than a folder.

elements.text: I'm looking into building a static app using PackageCompiler, and I was initially hoping to be able to have a single self-contained binary file that I could run. It appears that I get a directory instead, with a lib folder etc. Could someone please help me understand what role all of this plays, and whether or not any of it can be discarded? Having a single binary (statically linked) is much nicer to distribute and run than a folder.

messages.text: hmm... not sure if here is the correct place to ask. What is the differences between `@ccallable` and `@cfunction`?

elements.text: hmm... not sure if here is the correct place to ask. What is the differences between
@ccallable
and
@cfunction

messages.text: The first one is to create an unmangled symbol in the sysimage so you can call it from c after linking with the library, the second one is so you can pass that function to a c function expecting a callback.

elements.text: The first one is to create an unmangled symbol in the sysimage so you can call it from c after linking with the library, the second one is so you can pass that function to a c function expecting a callback.

messages.text: What Kristoffer just said :wink: `@ccallable` is equivalent to `@cfunction` + an exported name.

elements.text: What Kristoffer just said
@ccallable
is equivalent to
@cfunction
+ an exported name.

messages.text: Thanks for the answers, I was able to find `@cfunction` but not `@ccallable` on the documentation

elements.text: Thanks for the answers, I was able to find
@cfunction
but not
@ccallable
on the documentation

messages.text: stupid questions ... can I guarantee that `PackageCompiler.jl` compiles all the functions and that I need and never call JIT generation? is this possible?

elements.text: stupid questions ... can I guarantee that
PackageCompiler.jl
compiles all the functions and that I need and never call JIT generation? is this possible?

messages.text: There is no guarantee of that right now.

elements.text: There is no guarantee of that right now.

messages.text: is there a way to minimize it? for example, using `SnoopCompile.jl`?

elements.text: is there a way to minimize it? for example, using
SnoopCompile.jl

messages.text: You can use `SnoopCompile`, generate a precompile file and give it as `precompile_statements_file`, or you have a representative workload and give it as `precompile_execution_file` as shown in e.g. <https://julialang.github.io/PackageCompiler.jl/dev/examples/plots/>.

elements.text: You can use
SnoopCompile
, generate a precompile file and give it as
precompile_statements_file
, or you have a representative workload and give it as
precompile_execution_file
as shown in e.g.

messages.text: yes thanks! I have read those sections already, however as you mentioned that can't guarantee that all the functions are compiled. I am looking for "extra things" that I could do to minimize that.

elements.text: yes thanks! I have read those sections already, however as you mentioned that can't guarantee that all the functions are compiled. I am looking for "extra things" that I could do to minimize that.

messages.text: the problem is that I am trying to embed a Julia algorithm on a C/C++ system.

elements.text: What is a C/C++ system and how is it related to not allowing any JIT whatsoever?

messages.text: GH is having some issues right now, but my PR <https://github.com/JuliaLang/julia/pull/39129> will eventually make it possible to disable codegen entirely <@U013V2CFZAN>

elements.text: GH is having some issues right now, but my PR
will eventually make it possible to disable codegen entirely

messages.text: Confirming that your code will never *need* to JIT compile, and will still function properly, is a much harder question to answer

need
to JIT compile, and will still function properly, is a much harder question to answer

messages.text: <@U67D54KS8> it is a high throughput "robotics" system, basically a motorized stage. Many calculations need to be done beforehand and having consistent timings is mandatory. There could be small variations though

messages.text: Question for PackageCompiler maintainers: how would you feel about my adding a (potentially optional) dependency on GPUCompiler to PackageCompiler, and modifying `create_app` to get "static" codegen support? It would only support code signatures that don't do dynamic dispatch, at the moment.

elements.text: Question for PackageCompiler maintainers: how would you feel about my adding a (potentially optional) dependency on GPUCompiler to PackageCompiler, and modifying
create_app
to get "static" codegen support? It would only support code signatures that don't do dynamic dispatch, at the moment.

messages.text: The static codegen variant of `create_app` would be opt-in, of course

elements.text: The static codegen variant of
create_app
would be opt-in, of course

messages.text: Or it could be a different function altogether

elements.text: Or it could be a different function altogether

messages.text: I think to start with, it would be better to have that as a separate package. Once that has proven itself to be stable and useful, it can be brought into PackageCompiler

elements.text: I think to start with, it would be better to have that as a separate package. Once that has proven itself to be stable and useful, it can be brought into PackageCompiler

messages.text: Sounds good!

elements.text: Sounds good!
